words.def: The characteristic of the field F is the smallest positive integer n such that n·1 = 0; here n·1 stands for n summands 1 + 1 + 1 + ... + 1. If no such n exists, we say the characteristic is zero. Every non-zero characteristic is a prime number. For example, the rational numbers, the real numbers and the p-adic numbers have characteristic 0, while the finite field Zp has characteristic p.
words.name: Characteristic

words.def: A subfield of a field F is a subset of F which is closed under the field operation + and * of F and which, with these operations, forms itself a field.
words.name: Subfield

words.def: The prime field of the field F is the unique smallest subfield of F.
words.name: Prime field

words.def: If F is a subfield of E then E is an extension field of F. We then also say that E/F is a field extension.
words.name: Extension field

words.def: Given an extension E/F, the field E can be considered as a vector space over the field F, and the dimension of this vector space is the degree of the extension, denoted by [E : F].
words.name: Degree of an extension

words.def: A finite extension is a field extension whose degree is finite.
words.name: Finite extension

words.def: If an element α of an extension field E over F is the root of a non-zero polynomial in F[x], then α is algebraic over F. If every element of E is algebraic over F, then E/F is an algebraic extension.
words.name: Algebraic extension

words.def: Given a field extension E/F and a subset S of E, we write F(S) for the smallest subfield of E that contains both F and S. It consists of all the elements of E that can be obtained by repeatedly using the operations +,−,*,/ on the elements of F and S. If E = F(S) we say that E is generated by S over F.
words.name: Generating set

words.def: An element α of an extension field E over a field F is called a primitive element if E=F(α), the smallest extension field containing α. Such an extension is called a simple extension.
words.name: Primitive element

words.def: A field extension generated by the complete factorisation of a polynomial.
words.name: Splitting field

words.def: A field extension generated by the complete factorisation of a set of polynomials.
words.name: Normal extension

words.def: An extension generated by roots of separable polynomials.
words.name: Separable extension

words.def: A field such that every finite extension is separable. All fields of characteristic zero, and all finite fields, are perfect.
words.name: Perfect field

words.def: Let F be a field of characteristic p>0; then Fp is a subfield. The degree [F:Fp] is called the imperfect degree of F. The field F is perfect if and only if its imperfect degree is 1. For example, if F is a function field of n variables over a finite field of characteristic p>0, then its imperfect degree is pn.[1]
words.name: Imperfect degree

words.def: A field F is algebraically closed if every polynomial in F[x] has a root in F; equivalently: every polynomial in F[x] is a product of linear factors.
words.name: Algebraically closed field

words.def: An algebraic closure of a field F is an algebraic extension of F which is algebraically closed. Every field has an algebraic closure, and it is unique up to an isomorphism that fixes F.
words.name: Algebraic closure

words.def: Those elements of an extension field of F that are not algebraic over F are transcendental over F.
words.name: Transcendental

words.def: Elements of an extension field of F are algebraically independent over F if they don't satisfy any non-zero polynomial equation with coefficients in F.
words.name: Algebraically independent elements

words.def: The number of algebraically independent transcendental elements in a field extension. It is used to define the dimension of an algebraic variety.
words.name: Transcendence degree

words.def:
A field homomorphism between two fields E and F is a function

f : E → F
words.name: Field homomorphism

words.def: A field with finitely many elements.
words.name: Finite field

words.def: A field with a total order compatible with its operations.
words.name: Ordered field

words.def: Finite extension of the field of rational numbers.
words.name: Number field

words.def: The field of algebraic numbers is the smallest algebraically closed extension of the field of rational numbers. Their detailed properties are studied in algebraic number theory.
words.name: Algebraic numbers

words.def: A degree-two extension of the rational numbers.
words.name: Quadratic field

words.def: An extension of the rational numbers generated by a root of unity.
words.name: Cyclotomic field

words.def: A number field generated by a root of a polynomial, having all its roots real numbers.
words.name: Totally real field

words.def: A number field or a function field of one variable over a finite field.
words.name: Global field

words.def: A completion of some global field (w.r.t. a prime of the integer ring).
words.name: Local field

words.def: A field complete w.r.t. to some valuation.
words.name: Complete field

words.def: A field in which every variety has a rational point.[2]
words.name: Pseudo algebraically closed field

words.def: A field satisfying Hensel lemma w.r.t. some valuation. A generalization of complete fields.
words.name: Henselian field

words.def: A field satisfying Hilbert's irreducibility theorem: formally, one for which the projective line is not thin in the sense of Serre.[3][4]
words.name: Hilbertian field

words.def: A totally real algebraic number field or a totally imaginary quadratic extension of a totally real field.[5]
words.name: Kroneckerian field

words.def: An algebraic number field which is a totally imaginary quadratic extension of a totally real field.[6]
words.name: CM-field or J-field

words.def: A field over which no biquaternion algebra is a division algebra.[7]
words.name: Linked field

words.def: A pseudo algebraically closed field whose absolute Galois group has the embedding property.[8]
words.name: Frobenius field

words.def: An extension in which every element of E is algebraic over F.
words.name: Algebraic extension

words.def: An extension which is generated by a single element, called a primitive element, or generating element.[9] The primitive element theorem classifies such extensions.[10]
words.name: Simple extension

words.def: An extension that splits a family of polynomials: every root of the minimal polynomial of an element of E over F is also in E.
words.name: Normal extension

words.def: An algebraic extension in which the minimal polynomial of every element of E over F is a separable polynomial, that is, has distinct roots.[11]
words.name: Separable extension

words.def: A normal, separable field extension.
words.name: Galois extension

words.def: An extension E/F such that the algebraic closure of F in E is purely inseparable over F; equivalently, E is linearly disjoint from the separable closure of F.[12]
words.name: Primary extension

words.def: An extension E/F in which every element of E not in F is transcendental over F.[13][14]
words.name: Purely transcendental extension

words.def: An extension E/F such that E is separable over F and F is algebraically closed in E.[12]
words.name: Regular extension

words.def:
A simple extension E/F generated by a single element α satisfying 
  
    
      
        
          α
          
            n
          
        
        =
        b
      
    
    {\displaystyle \alpha ^{n}=b}
  
 for an element b of F. In characteristic p, we also take an extension by a root of an Artin–Schreier polynomial to be a simple radical extension.[15]
words.name: Simple radical extension

words.def:
A tower 
  
    
      
        F
        =
        
          F
          
            0
          
        
        <
        
          F
          
            1
          
        
        <
        ⋯
        <
        
          F
          
            k
          
        
        =
        E
      
    
    {\displaystyle F=F_{0}<F_{1}<\cdots <F_{k}=E}
  
 where each extension 
  
    
      
        
          F
          
            i
          
        
        
          /
        
        
          F
          
            i
            −
            1
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle F_{i}/F_{i-1}}
  
 is a simple radical extension.[15]
words.name: Radical extension

words.def: An extension E/F such that E⊗FE is an integral domain.[16]
words.name: Self-regular extension

words.def: An extension E/F such that F is algebraically closed in F.[14]
words.name: Totally transcendental extension

words.def:
A class C of field extensions with the three properties[17]

If E is a C-extension of F and F is a C-extension of K then E is a C-extension of K.
If E and F are C-extensions of K in a common overfield M, then the compositum EF is a C-extension of K.
If E is a C-extension of F and E>K>F then E is a C-extension of K.
words.name: Distinguished class

words.def: A normal, separable field extension.
words.name: Galois extension

words.def: The automorphism group of a Galois extension. When it is a finite extension, this is a finite group of order equal to the degree of the extension. Galois groups for infinite extensions are profinite groups.
words.name: Galois group

words.def: The Galois theory of taking n-th roots, given enough roots of unity. It includes the general theory of quadratic extensions.
words.name: Kummer theory

words.def: Covers an exceptional case of Kummer theory, in characteristic p.
words.name: Artin–Schreier theory

words.def: A basis in the vector space sense of L over K, on which the Galois group of L over K acts transitively.
words.name: Normal basis

words.def: A different foundational piece of algebra, including the compositum operation (join of fields).
words.name: Tensor product of fields

words.def: Given a group G, find an extension of the rational number or other field with G as Galois group.
words.name: Inverse problem of Galois theory

words.def: The subject in which symmetry groups of differential equations are studied along the lines traditional in Galois theory. This is actually an old idea, and one of the motivations when Sophus Lie founded the theory of Lie groups. It has not, probably, reached definitive form.
words.name: Differential Galois theory

words.def: A very abstract approach from algebraic geometry, introduced to study the analogue of the fundamental group.
words.name: Grothendieck's Galois theory
